body.name: The Paris Notebook: An utterly gripping and emotional WW2 historical fiction novel, based on a true story

manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: Beneath a Starless Sky The Light We Left Behind

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars High Octane Suspense
reviews.reviewText: If you like lots of drama and “high octane” suspense, buy the book. The author does and superb job of keeping the reader up long after bed time.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Interesting World War II Story
reviews.reviewText: The “Paris notebook” of the title contains the notes of a psychologist who treated Adolf Hitler during World War I, describing the Fuhrer as a dangerous and unstable personality. The novel describes the struggles Katja Heinz, the assistant of the treating doctor, to publish the notebook and bring the mental deficiencies and danger of Hitler to public attention.This fast-paced novel kept my attention and interest through to the end. Although there were a lot of coincidences and near misses, and a bit too much romance for my taste, it was well written and will appeal to many readers who will root for Katja to get the notebook to the proper authorities and find happiness at last.I received a complimentary copy of this book. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Caught me from the start
reviews.reviewText: From beginning to end, the action, suspense, romance and intrigue captured and kept me through it all.Definitely a "page turner" !Really appreciated the writing style and "clean" nature, as well.Highly recommend.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I found the book absolutely spellbinding. It was different from some of the World War II books that I have read.Kat ja lives in Hamburg with her widowed mother. When she gets a job as the secretary of psychiatrist Dr.Viktor, one of the jobs is to type out the patients information from the doctors notes. Imagine her surprise when she uncovers that Dr.Viktor’s delusional patient was Adolf Hitler. Because of this, her work has to be done in the utmost secrecy.The book was a real page turner. Dr. Viktor and Kat ja put their lives at risk to keep this information safe and to make certain that it gets to the right hands. The storyline moves fast at times but there is also attention to detail.The characters are complex and well developed and this made it an enjoyable read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed Tessa Harris’ book The Light We Left Behind so I was optimistic about The Paris Notebook as well — especially with such a vibrant cover! While I can’t say it surpassed The Light We Left Behind for me, it was still quite an interesting read.When Katja takes a job at a clinic. Doctor Viktor assigns her the task of typing up secret medical records belonging to Adolf Hitler. She is persuaded by the doctor to take the manuscript to Paris with him. They do so at great risk, having to evade the Nazi spies.I didn’t click with the characters as much as I would have liked to. The plot was interesting and unique, however, I didn’t feel myself hanging onto every word. Still, it was an enjoyable read. I always enjoy finding WWII fiction that can stand out against the typical formulas.A huge thanks to Harper360 for sending me a free (US) ARC of the book! I have also purchased the Kindle edition.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars can’t put down
reviews.reviewText: This book is very well written! It is a little slow to get into but once you’re hooked, you can’t put it down!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Very much liked the main characters! The story line made you feel you were in the story! Very enjoyable and a fluid read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A beautiful love story!
reviews.reviewText: This is a magnificent love story about two young lovers who met in Germany just before Hitler began invading Poland at the beginning of World War II. Only their compassion and determination could save them from being victims of the greatest evil the world has ever known.

This book was amazing. I enjoyed reading this book from beginning to end.The story was so interesting and I just could not put it down.I have read several of Tessa Harris books and have always enjoyed them.I look forward to new books in the future from her.Thank you so much.James De GruchyMilton, Ontario Canada

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 5, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This novel was based on fact which made it much more interesting it tells the story of the psychiatric medical records of Adolf Hitler from the 1st World War that did exist.The book traces the story of Katya and Daniel as they try to get the notes published in war torn Europe during WW2.I found the book very enjoyable to read and it was well, written.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: A highly original and totally compelling wartime story
reviews.reviewText: There are times when I think I might be growing tired of wartime stories – and then a book like this one comes along, beautifully written and with such stunning originality, and I wonder what on earth why on earth I ever thought that. A piece of fiction, but built around a kernel of truth, with real events, characters and locations – the author’s afterword is almost as fascinating as the book itself – with an added layer of “what if” that made it a totally compelling story.In 1939 Hamburg, with the Nazi threat becoming ever more evident, Katja – struggling with the care of her frail mother, and her own grief over the death of her activist father in the early book burnings – unexpectedly secures a job as personal assistant to psychiatrist Doctor Viktor. Entrusted with the transcription of a notebook, she slowly realises that the clinical notes she’s working on have an immense importance – the doctor treated Adolf Hitler following a gas attack in WW1, and they hold major secrets about his mental health that, if shared, could have a considerable value in changing the course of history. She travels with the doctor to Paris, in an attempt to get the notes published – and, as an avid book lover, finds herself in Shakespeare and Company, where she meets Daniel. He’s a newspaper journalist, struggling with the recent loss of his wife and child, drinking too much – but, as Katja’s world falls apart, might just offer her the support she needs to achieve her aim of getting the notebook and its important information into allied hands and into the public domain.Katja is a quite wonderful heroine – young and at first naive, but with a developing steely determination to achieve her objective, showing exceptional bravery in the furtherance of the mission she really believes in. And I entirely believed in her, willing her on at every turn and through every heartbreaking setback. The world the author builds around her is wonderfully researched and recreated, and searingly real – the well-drawn individuals who stand in her way and work against her, the support she finds when her task seems impossible, the increase of Nazi oppression in Hamburg itself and the approaching threat of invasion when in Paris. The writing is just wonderful – after a necessarily steady start to introduce the characters and their context, the tension and pace really ramp up together with that feeling of suspense and mounting danger that made the book quite impossible to set aside. There’s a lot of exceptionally well-developed drama, but there’s a relationship story in here too – an all-consuming love story that had the perfect emotional touch, very real and particularly engaging, between two characters who already held my heart in their hands.This book really was quite exceptional in so many ways – without question one of my books of the year, with an unforgettable impact, and I recommend it really highly.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 4, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: Stunning WW2 novel set in Germany and France that combines high suspense with a sweeping romance
reviews.reviewText: What if it was spring 1939… and you knew a secret so damaging it could topple Hitler.German Katja does and the exciting premise of this beautifully written novel is how that secret is the true and very unstable state of the furthers mental (ill) health.Like Tessa’s previous book, “The Light We Left Behind” this novel takes a true, largely unknown nugget of WW2 history and transforms it into in a captivating, emotionally charged story.Here the ’nugget’ is how in 1918, a young Adolf was treated by a psychiatrist following a mustard gas attack. It can be presumed that any mind doctor would have identified a serious mental disorder in this patient. We know the doctor’s name and that he made full notes. But not what had happened to them by the time war broke out.So the ‘gold’ of this nugget is how might Europe in1939 react if that doctor was able to tell the world what Hitler was really like. Could the war be stopped, even before it started?This is Katja's fervent belief. We meet her as her boss, psychiatrist Dr Viktor tasks her with typing up those notes - the Paris Notebook of the title. Such is her courage that she will go on to risk her life, and the lives of those that she loves as she strives to make public the notes.Whilst the plotting is stunning - especially as it weaves between Berlin and Paris - it is the integrity and believability of the characters that made me gasp. I was by turns scared, excited and consumed with Katja and sad, furious, amused and enthralled by Daniel, an Irish writer she meets in Paris.Other characters are superbly drawn too. Katja’s anxious mother. Daniel’s bohemian friends. You feel what they endure in 1930s Germany; you soak up the innocence in a France yet to fall.The main action takes place over around eight months. I got into the story right from page one and could have read and read on without putting it down. However! As with books that I truly love, I decided to savour this one and split it over several weekends, all the more to soak up the authentic period detail and the joy of reading about characters who do what it right, not what is easy.I adored this book.I gasped. I cried. Finally - I sat back satisfied. I’d been on an exhilarating journey - and it had been very worthwhile.If you enjoy novels with strong characters and plots that you cannot predict, then I am sure that you will love it too. A highly deserved Five Stars

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 16, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This book was so good until the unrealistic pathetic ending ruined it all. Such a shame. Worth reading if you don't mind crappy endings.
